Dr. King's life should push all of us to not shy away from the gravest injustices and the toughest fights. This is a moment for all of us to ask ourselves what we are called to do. "Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that."

The fact that black men and women do not earn a dollar on the dollar in the workplace as a white man has to be my fight too. Because if I really care about every child as much as I do my own, then these are my fights to help overcome too.

The fact that a black woman in New York City is 12 times more likely to die in childbirth is outrageous, and it's all of our responsibility to fix that. The fact that a young black or brown man is 10 times more likely to be arrested for marijuana possession is all of our burden.

Fighting racism and injustice will take all of us <U+2014> it cannot be left to people of color alone. White people like me need to take up our part of this burden, and commit to using our voices to amplify those that have been ignored and silenced for too long.

Today, so many decades after Dr. King's assassination, we need more than ever to have an honest conversation about racism: not just individual acts, but the systemic, institutional racism infecting our society <U+2014> our healthcare, education, criminal justice system, and economy.

As we honor Dr. King today, we should all think, What am I doing with MY own time here on this earth to serve others? Because he taught us that serving others is the greatest purpose in life. And as he said, <U+201C>The time is always right to do what is right.<U+201D>

Dr. King continues to inspire us because he believed in values that transcend time and movements: He believed in right vs. wrong; that only light can drive out darkness; that we're all called to fight for others, because an injustice against one is an injustice against all.

Judge Kavanaugh<U+2019>s confirmation just cemented Nov. 6 as one of the most important elections of our lifetimes. We<U+2019>ve spoken out time and again. We have the chance to change who represents us this November <U+2013> a chance to make sure it<U+2019>s people we can count on to do the right thing.

We must keep fighting to be a country that values women. A country that empowers them to raise their voices and actually listens to what they have to say. A country that believes their stories. A country whose potential will always be tied to women<U+2019>s progress.

Don<U+2019>t get fed up. Get fired up. Hold onto the hurt and anger you feel now to fuel our fight forward. We need to organize, volunteer and donate to defeat everyone who wouldn<U+2019>t listen. We need to go to the ballot box on Nov. 6 and vote for candidates who share our values.

But make no mistake: Our fight was not for nothing. The bravery of Dr. Ford<U+2019>s testimony inspired women everywhere. Her strength will forever be a source of strength as we continue to fight for survivors to be believed, for women to be valued. And we won<U+2019>t stop fighting.

The Senate confirmed Judge Kavanaugh against the will of millions of Americans. So many called their senators to ask they vote no. Women stepped forward with stories of experiencing the horrors and trauma of sexual assault.

In a few hours, the U.S. Senate will turn its back on righteousness, on fairness, on reason. And make no mistake, it will turn its back on women. 

Don't let this silence you. Don't lose hope. Because millions are watching this moment <U+2014> and we will rise up and fight back.

From the first moments of this administration, women have marched. But these aren<U+2019>t walks in the park. When we march, we do it together, with purpose and for our future. We won<U+2019>t be silent. We won<U+2019>t stop.
Do Senate Republicans believe women? Do they value our stories? Do they trust what we share about our experiences? Their answers will be recorded for history when we vote on Judge Kavanaugh.

What we've seen over the last few weeks is an exercise of power. Instead of getting to the truth, we've witnessed those in power ram though a Supreme Court nominee who is completely unfit to serve. 

But things are changing and they are changing fast. November is coming.

I want to make clear to every woman and every survivor that I hear you, that I will keep fighting for you, and that you will not remain unheard. 

This morning, I'll share your stories from the Senate floor. Tune in at 6am on @CSPAN.

Funding would be prioritized for hospitals serving low-income communities and rural populations, and would help the medical community better identify and respond to signs of pregnancy complications.

High standards of maternal care are lacking broadly <U+2013> and are particularly missing in hospitals serving women of color. Black women in New York City are 12 times more likely than white women to lose their lives as a result of pregnancy and childbirth. We can<U+2019>t accept this.

Mothers are dying every day <U+2013> and for each one who dies, another 70 nearly do. 60% of pregnancy-related deaths are from preventable complications like hemorrhage, preeclampsia and sepsis. We're failing women and babies.

While other developed nations<U+2019> maternal mortality rates drastically decline, ours is on the rise. In fact, we are 1 of just 8 countries in the entire world with increasing rates of maternal mortality. Our nation is in crisis.

More women die from complications giving birth in the U.S. than in any other developed country. Black mothers are 3 to 4 times more likely to die than white mothers <U+2013> a rate not tied to income level or education, but race alone. That<U+2019>s why I<U+2019>m introducing the MOMS Act. Thread:

Financial services and payday lender lobbyists will fight this hard, but we need to fight harder. It's simple: we should put people above profit. Join this fight: Make sure your interests are represented in Congress and raise your voice.

This is a simple solution to a problem facing every state in this country. In 2006, payday loans were so bad that Congress had to pass a law to ban them from preying on military service members. We should offer the same protections to everyone with an alternative to endless debt.

The federal government has backed financial institutions directly & indirectly for decades with FDIC insurance, FHA backing, & bailouts. But those <U+201C>for profit<U+201D> banks have left too many behind. It's time to close the gap<U+2014>and this time, no one will get rich on the taxpayers dime.
And, most importantly, this bill will help many low-income workers begin to save and accumulate wealth, empowering our underserved communities to build financial success for generations.

The Post Office has 30,000 locations across the country, making this an efficient and elegant solution for the millions of <U+201C>unbanked<U+201D> and "underbanked" in communities with no options. This bill will cost taxpayers nothing, and will also strengthen the Post Office's finances.

Payday lending traps compound the financial struggles of many hardworking people who are struggling to get by. It makes it expensive to be poor. A simple short-term $50 loan to pay a utility bill or repair a car could end up costing 400% more to repay in just two weeks!
This idea could wipe out the predatory practices of the payday loan industry overnight by providing an accessible and low cost alternative.

Today, the Supreme Court begins hearing oral arguments in Janus vs. AFSCME Council 31, a case that is a direct attack on public-sector unions and our workers<U+2019> ability to organize to improve their wages and working conditions.

Listening makes change. Learning from others<U+2019> stories makes change. That<U+2019>s why it<U+2019>s important that these courageous students are speaking truth to power. As I prepare to make our case to my colleagues tomorrow, I urge you to keep speaking out. Raise your voices. Call for change.

The minute you meet a parent who<U+2019>s lost a teenage child to gun violence, everything changes. From that moment, and for my entire service in the Senate, I<U+2019>ve proudly voted against the NRA and have had an <U+201C>F<U+201D> rating.

I came from a hunting family and when I first came to Congress, I had an <U+201C>A<U+201D> rating from the NRA. But 9 years ago when I came to the Senate, I met with the victims of gun violence and listened to their stories.

These votes are about keeping our children safe in schools. These votes will help keep people safe on the streets of their own communities. These votes will honor the tireless work of activists who<U+2019>ve been speaking out against the scourge of gun violence for years.

We need to ban semi-automatic assault weapons & bump stocks.
We need to pass universal background checks & close the gun show loophole.
We need to make sure those with a history of violent crimes cannot get guns.
Tomorrow, I<U+2019>m calling on my colleagues to do something about this. We need a vote.

Enough is enough. The NRA may be powerful, but so are you and your voice. I urge you to speak out and say shame on any lawmaker who won<U+2019>t stand up to the NRA. Pay attention. Find out who. Vote them out this November.

Let me make this clear: This has nothing to do with the Second Amendment and everything to do with greed. The NRA doesn<U+2019>t care about people <U+2013> they care about money, and that<U+2019>s it.

If my colleagues in Congress are so beholden to the NRA, so paralyzed by its chokehold, that they will turn their backs and bury their heads once again while more children die <U+2013> then this is a monumental failure in leadership.

After this terrible tragedy in Parkland, we<U+2019>re seeing the same thing from Congress that we saw after Sandy Hook, after Aurora, after Charleston, after San Bernardino, after Orlando, after Las Vegas, after Sutherland Springs: complete inaction.
